item.title: Introduction
item.description:
What is Windows on Fridges?

Windows on Fridges is an end-to-end solution that makes use of the Microsoft Developer Platform for IoT with an Intel Galileo board, and Microsoft Azure web services.

It is the intern project for the 2014 Explorer interns on the Internet of Things Experiences Team. The original conception of this project was to create an autonomous robot that would deliver drinks to your office.

The End-to-end

The full end to end consists of multiple different pieces.

  • Web application that allows users to input a room they want a drink delivered to.
  • Pathfinding service that is hosted on azure.
  • REST server that interacts with the client.
  • Client application which interacts directly with the hardware.
  • Firmata the protocol running on the Galileo.

All together this allows a user to input the room they want a drink delivered to. The path is then calculated and converted to a list of instructions that are then sent to the REST server. The REST server then sends the list to the client over a websocket connection. The client uses a Firmata client library to communicate with the hardware.

item.title: Getting Started
item.description:
Step 1. Get Hello Blinky running on your board.

Follow the instructions for Hello Blinky. This will ensure that you can create projects and deploy to your board.

This tutorial will assume a general level of understanding of the Galileo Development Platform for Windows.

Step 2. Install Project Dependencies

This project requires a few extra peices of software.

  • Git
  • NodeJS
  • Python

Step 3. Setup Azure

This step is not required as everything can be hosted locally.

At this point if you do want to use Azure, just create an account.

item.title: Build
item.description:
Building the Robot

Steps

  1. Follow the getting started guide to get hello blinky working with Galileo for Windows. $(external link to docs)
  2. Connect the motor shield to the galileo and attach the 2 motors to the shield.
  3. Find the Sample Project in $(samples repository) named FirmataForGalileo and open the solution.
  4. Run the solution on the remote debugger.
  5. Install Nodejs
  6. Clone the wof-nodebot repo
  7. To run the node server, execute the following command in cmd line
    npm install

You will need to add node and npm to your path. 5. Run the node server either on the Galileo or from a computer and pick the IP address accordingly. Run the server with

   node server.js

from the wof-nodebot directory. 6. Use curl to send a post request to http:///robot in the post body include

{ 
  "direction" : "left/right/forward/backward", 
  "speed":0-255, 
  "duration":2000 
}

Steps when debugging

  • Run Firmata on the Galileo from Visual Studio.
  • Run the Node server from cmd line.
  • If you have to stop the node server or Firmata currently you must reboot the Galileo.
